clean_content:
Definition / general

* Oral varicosities are tortuous and aberrantly dilated venous structures that most often present on the lips and ventral tongue of older individuals* They represent a developmental anomaly of unknown etiology with minimal clinical implications

Essential features

* Abnormally dilated venous structures* The most common oral mucosal lesion in older adults ([J Dent Res Dent Clin Dent Prospects 2019;13:24](31217915))* Most often found under the tongue and around the lips / labial mucosa

Terminology

* Varicosity / varicosities* Varix* Varices* Caviar tongue* Phlebectasia linguae

ICD coding

* ICD-10: [I86.0](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/I00-I99/I80-I89/I86-/I86.0) - Sublingual varices* IDC-10: [I86.8](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/I00-I99/I80-I89/I86-/I86.8) - Varices of unspecified locations

Epidemiology

* Older individuals (67% of patients are > 60 years) ([Clin Dermatol 2016;34:458](27343960))

Sites

* Sublingual varices are most common* May also be found on skin of lip, labial mucosa or buccal mucosa

Etiology

* Unknown etiology* Loosely associated risk factors include smoking, cardiovascular disease (e.g. hypertension), female gender, denture wearing, chronic liver disease and old age ([Clin Dermatol 2016;34:458](27343960), [Folia Morphol (Warsz) 2019;78:325](30371931), [Medicine (Baltimore) 2019;98:e16987](31626079), [Saudi Med J 2015;36:310](25737173), [BMC Oral Health 2015;15:78](26163474))

Clinical features

* Presents as a chain of compressible blue-purple nodules on either side of the lingual frenum or as a single elevated or flat submucosal nodule in other locations* May be firm when thrombosed* Ventral tongue is the most common site, although also found on labial mucosa, skin of lip, buccal mucosa or other rare oral sites* Painless and often inconsequential ([Gerodontology 2015;32:82](23992044))

Diagnosis

* Diagnosis often is made on clinical presentation, especially when in the sublingual location; biopsy often is not required* Diascopy may prove useful in differential diagnosis, as varicosities demonstrate blanching ([Gerodontology 2015;32:82](23992044))* A single varicosity may be diagnosed upon histologic examination when the presentation is not clinically diagnostic

Radiology description

* Occasionally, oral varicosities may demonstrate small opacifications on radiographic imaging due to phlebolith formation within a thrombus ([Gerodontology 2015;32:82](23992044))

Prognostic factors

* Varicosities are of little clinical consequence* Patients have a good prognosis, although rare cases may be associated with bleeding ([Medicine (Baltimore) 2019;98:e16987](31626079))

Case reports

* 42 year old woman with bleeding varicosity at base of tongue in association with liver cirrhosis ([Medicine (Baltimore) 2019;98:e16987](31626079))* 60 year old white woman with oral varicosity treated with sclerotherapy ([Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal 2006;11:E44](16388293))* 62 year old woman with lingual varicosities visualized via dermoscopy / mucoscopy ([Dermatol Pract Concept 2018;8:54](29445577))

Treatment

* Varicosities generally are not treated unless thrombosed or displeasing to the patient in form or function
  + In such cases, conservative surgical excision or sclerotherapy is sufficient ([Med Oral Patol Oral Cir Bucal 2018;23:e180](29476682))* Safe and effective treatment has been performed with diode and Nd:YAG lasers ([J Contemp Dent Pract 2015;16:723](26522597))

Clinical images

Contributed by Molly Housley Smith, D.M.D.  

[![Sublingual varicosities](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityvarixsmith01.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityvarixsmith01.jpg)

Sublingual varicosities

[![Varicosity on lower lip](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityvarixsmith02.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityvarixsmith02.jpg)

Varicosity on lower lip

[![Thrombosed varicosity of labial mucosa](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityvarixsmith03.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityvarixsmith03.jpg)

Thrombosed varicosity of labial mucosa

Gross description

* Tan surface with raised or flat blue-purple-black ovoid structure, which may be firm or depressible* Cut surface shows dilated or collapsed vascular space that may demonstrate luminal accumulation of brown erythrocytes

Gross images

Contributed by Molly Housley Smith, D.M.D.  

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityvarixsmith04.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityvarixsmith04.jpg)

Oral varicosity

Microscopic (histologic) description

* 1 - 3 tortuous, enlarged venous structures lined by a thin layer of endothelium ([Gerodontology 2015;32:82](23992044))* Thrombosis or organizing thrombosis is often present, which is depicted by concentric layers of erythrocytes and platelets, referred to as lines of Zahn
    + Aggregates of granulation tissue may also be present during formation* Concentric rings of eosinophilic calcifications may be present within the lumen

Microscopic (histologic) images

Contributed by Molly Housley Smith, D.M.D.  

[![Oral varicosity](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityvarixsmith05.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityvarixsmith05.jpg)

Oral varicosity

[![Compressed oral varicosity](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityvarixsmith06.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityvarixsmith06.jpg)

Compressed oral varicosity

[![Oral varicosity with organizing thrombus](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityvarixsmith07.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityvarixsmith07.jpg)

Oral varicosity with organizing thrombus

[![Phlebolith formation](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityvarixsmith08.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityvarixsmith08.jpg)

Phlebolith formation

Negative stains

* [GLUT1](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsglut1.html) ([Oral Dis 2007;13:51](17241430))

Sample pathology report

* Lower lip, excision:
  + Vascular anomaly consistent with varicosity

Differential diagnosis

* Sublingual varicosities are clinically diagnostic and do not require biopsy* Clinical differential diagnosis for a single, blue oral varix may include the following:
    + [Hemangioma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavityhobnailhemangioma.html):
      - An abnormal collection of more than 3 dilated vessels, seen on light microscopy- Congenital- Often [GLUT1](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsglut1.html) positive ([Oral Dis 2007;13:51](17241430))+ [Vascular leiomyoma (angioleiomyoma)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/softtissueangioleiomyoma.html):
        - Histopathologic examination reveals a well defined proliferation of smooth muscle emanating from vascular walls- Positive for [alpha smooth muscle actin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsalphasmoothmuscleactin.html)+ **Salivary tumors / reactive processes**, differentiated upon biopsy:
          - [Mucoepidermoid carcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitymucoep.html)- [Mucocele](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitymucocele.html)- [Salivary duct cyst](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitysalivaryductcyst.html)+ **Amalgam tattoo**:
            - May demonstrate opacification on radiograph- Flat, blue-black pigmentation- Histopathologic examination reveals foreign particles within connective tissue+ **Melanocytic nevus** (especially [blue nevus](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skintumormelanocyticbluenevus.html)):
              - Histopathologic examination reveals focal collection of melanocytes+ [Melanoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitymelanoma.html):
                - Often irregular borders- Histopathologic examination reveals abnormal increase in melanocytes- Most common on the maxillary gingiva and hard palate+ [Focal melanosis / melanocytic macule](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitymelanotic.html):
                  - Flat, never raised- Focal accumulation of melanin without increase in melanocytes, seen on light microscopy

Additional references

* [Head Neck Pathol 2019;13:4](30693460)
